summary:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this document about Ahmed Abu Ismail in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The main points seem to be his role as an Egyptian economist and politician, his position as finance minister in the 1970s, his education, career moves, his economic views, and his legacy. 

He was born in 1915, studied at the University of Manchester, got a PhD in transport economics. Then he worked in the UK and Egypt, established a college in Kuwait. He supported a liberal economy but criticized the public sector's inefficiency. 

He was appointed finance minister in 1975 under Sadat, but he opposed IMF policies, leading to his dismissal in 1976. He later worked at a bank and in parliament. Died in 2013, and a district was named after him.

I need to make sure the summary includes his key roles, his economic stance, the conflict with IMF policies, and his legacy. Avoid minor details like the exact dates of his death and the district name unless necessary. Keep it concise, focusing on main topics and key concepts.
</think>

Ahmed Abu Ismail (1915–2013) was an Egyptian economist and politician known for his role as finance minister in the 1970s and his advocacy for liberal economic policies. Educated at the University of Manchester and a proponent of market-oriented reforms, he criticized Egypt's inefficient public sector while supporting price controls and subsidies during his tenure. Despite opposing IMF-imposed policies, he was dismissed in 1976, later serving in banking and politics. His legacy includes a district in his hometown, Samannud, named in his honor.

qa_pairs.chunk:
Chunk:

[S1] Ahmed Abu Ismail


# Ahmed Abu Ismail



**Ahmed Abu Ismail** (1915–2013) was an Egyptian economist and politician who served as minister of finance in the 1970s. [S2] ## Early life and education

Ismail was born in Samannud in March 1915. [S3] He hailed from a wealthy middle-class family. [S4] He attended the University of Manchester and obtained a PhD in transport economics in 1938. [S5] ## Career

Following his graduation Ismail worked at the University of London and returned to Egypt in 1948. [S6] Then he worked at an Egyptian university. [S7] He established the college of commerce of Kuwait University in 1968. [S8] Ismail supported a liberal economy approach and harshly criticized the inefficiency of the Egyptian public sector. [S9] Although Ismail acted as the leader of opponents of the public economy policy implemented by President Anwar Sadat, he was appointed finance minister on 16 April 1975, replacing Mohammed Hamdi El Nashar in the post. [S10] The cabinet was led by Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem. [S11] Ismail adhered to a liberal economic approach, but he was an advocate of the price control and the increased level of subsidies to improve the economy of Egypt when he was in office. [S12] Ismail's tenure ended on 19 November 1976 when he was dismissed due to his opposition over the policies imposed by the International Monetary Fund. [S13] The Economy Minister Zaki Shafei was also removed from office on the same date due to the same reason. [S14] Mohammed Salah Eldeen Hamid became finance minister replacing Ismail in the post. [S15] Then Ismail was named as the head of the Far East Bank in Cairo and served at the Parliament as a member of the New Wafd Party. [S16] ## Death and legacy

Ismail died in May 2013 and was buried in his hometown, Samannud. [S17] A district in Samannud was named after him in September 2013.

qa_pairs.chunk:
Chunk:

[S1] Ahmed Abu Ismail


# Ahmed Abu Ismail



**Ahmed Abu Ismail** (1915–2013) was an Egyptian economist and politician who served as minister of finance in the 1970s. [S2] ## Early life and education

Ismail was born in Samannud in March 1915. [S3] He hailed from a wealthy middle-class family. [S4] He attended the University of Manchester and obtained a PhD in transport economics in 1938. [S5] ## Career

Following his graduation Ismail worked at the University of London and returned to Egypt in 1948. [S6] Then he worked at an Egyptian university. [S7] He established the college of commerce of Kuwait University in 1968. [S8] Ismail supported a liberal economy approach and harshly criticized the inefficiency of the Egyptian public sector. [S9] Although Ismail acted as the leader of opponents of the public economy policy implemented by President Anwar Sadat, he was appointed finance minister on 16 April 1975, replacing Mohammed Hamdi El Nashar in the post. [S10] The cabinet was led by Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem. [S11] Ismail adhered to a liberal economic approach, but he was an advocate of the price control and the increased level of subsidies to improve the economy of Egypt when he was in office. [S12] Ismail's tenure ended on 19 November 1976 when he was dismissed due to his opposition over the policies imposed by the International Monetary Fund. [S13] The Economy Minister Zaki Shafei was also removed from office on the same date due to the same reason. [S14] Mohammed Salah Eldeen Hamid became finance minister replacing Ismail in the post. [S15] Then Ismail was named as the head of the Far East Bank in Cairo and served at the Parliament as a member of the New Wafd Party. [S16] ## Death and legacy

Ismail died in May 2013 and was buried in his hometown, Samannud. [S17] A district in Samannud was named after him in September 2013.
qa_pairs.question: Why was Ahmed Abu Ismail dismissed from his position as finance minister?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Ismail was dismissed from his position as finance minister due to his opposition over the policies imposed by the International Monetary Fund.<cite>[S13]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.thinking:
Okay, let's see. The question is asking why Ahmed Abu Ismail was dismissed from his position as finance minister. I need to look through the supporting context provided.

First, I'll scan the passage for mentions of his dismissal. The relevant part is in sentence S13: "Ismail's tenure ended on 19 November 1976 when he was dismissed due to his opposition over the policies imposed by the International Monetary Fund." That seems to directly answer the question. 

I should check if there's any other information that might be relevant. Sentence S14 mentions that Zaki Shafei was also removed on the same date for the same reason, which confirms that the reason was related to IMF policies. The answer is clearly stated in S13. No other sentences mention the dismissal. So the citation should be [S13].
